p: Shirin Adel Pilerood and Jamuna Prakash [ 50] reported in their study that a water extract of E. amoenum showed the highest antioxidant properties in a DPPH assay, whereas the acetone extracts showed the least activity. Petals of this species exhibited higher total phenolic content (TPC) (1540 mg/100 g), total flavonoid content (TFC) (4.54 ± 0.042 mg), and tannin content (2.47 ± 0.064 mg) when extracted by hot water. Overall, the antioxidant properties of E. amoenum could explain many of the biologically significant outcomes as recorded in the ethnomedicinal record. Moreover, this tradition of using tea (particularly in Iran) as a vehicle could be clinically significant, as water-based formulations are biologically applicable compared to organic solvents as formulations. However, it is always important to remember that water stable and soluble phytochemicals are not always bioavailable [ 53], and therefore hot water extracted phytochemicals from E. amoenum require further pharmacological investigation.
